80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:48): well, when I first mentioned nofollow, I was on about rel=nofollow, and yes, google suggested using that to combat spam, and have since recommended it for marking up ads as well
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:48): because they don't feel those links should pass PR
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:49): but the robots meta tag is a bit different
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:49): the W3C seems to think they aren't selling google juice, though
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:50): heh, well it's come up in SEO circles a few timesa about the 'paid links' the W3C has on that page
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): but it's pretty obvious that those who buy placement on that page think they are buying it
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:50): especially as it's a high authority domain
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:51): now and then i read something or hear something from these so-called SEO's and i often doubt they know what they're talking about
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:51): toolbar suggest that particular page has a PR of 8, a link from like that is worth a fair bit :)
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:52): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: there are lots of people who call themselves SEO guru's who think meta keywords still make a difference in ranking
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (13:52): on the other hand, there are numerous people who do have a clue :)
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (14:03): ok, having checked, it seems Matt Cutts has stated that meta nofollow does the same as rel=nofollow, so those links should indeed NOT be passing google juice
80a2d9aa2e7b8108d042b8b4b94c69c5 (14:04): the page is indexed, so the links can be found as part of the page, but they aren't benefiting the recipients in terms of link popularity :)
